name: Validate CAD and BIM Files Against Excel Standards (Revit, IFC, AutoCAD, DGN)

user.name: Artem Boiko
user.bio: Founder DataDrivenConstruction.io | AEC Tech Consultant & Automation Expert | Bridging Software and Construction

description:
*This workflow contains community nodes that are only compatible with the self-hosted version of n8n.*

## CAD-BIM Multi-Format Validation Pipeline

This workflow enables automated validation of CAD and BIM files in multiple formats (Revit, IFC, DWG, DGN) for compliance with project standards and requirements.

### Key Features

- Converts Revit, IFC, DWG, and DGN models into open data tables
- Runs automated validation checks on model naming, structure, attributes, and completeness
- Generates error reports and QTO (Quantity Take-Off) tables for all processed files

### How it works

1. Upload one or more project files in Revit (.rvt), IFC (.ifc), DWG, or DGN formats
2. The pipeline automatically processes each file and validates against configurable rules in Excel form
3. Error summaries and QTO tables are generated 
4. All outputs are available for download as Excel 


- **Converter Path:**  
  Make sure the converter executable (e.g. `RvtExporter.exe`) is placed in `DDC Exporter\datadrivenlibs\`.  
  Specify the full path in the workflow settings if required.



- **Troubleshooting:**  
  - If conversion fails, double-check the path to the executable.
  - Only supported formats can be processed (see GitHub Readme).
  - Review logs in `/output` for error details.

- **Docs & Issues:**  
  [Full Readme on GitHub](https://github.com/datadrivenconstruction/cad2data-Revit-IFC-DWG-DGN-pipeline-with-conversion-validation-qto)

## Consulting and Training
We work with leading construction, engineering, consulting agencies and technology firms around the world to help them implement open data principles, automate CAD/BIM processing and build robust ETL pipelines.

If you would like to test this solution with your own data, or are interested in adapting the workflow to real project tasks, feel free to contact us.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

data.details: The Code node allows you to execute JavaScript in your workflow.

parameters.content:
## üöÄ START WORKFLOW

Click "Execute Workflow" button to begin the validation process

## üìã VALIDATION RULES

**Specify the path to rules file:**
`validation_rules_path`

This file contains validation criteria

parameters.pythonCode:
def _disable_n8n_mitigations():
    import sys

    # n8n 1.99: blocked `os` module: https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/pull/15970
    sys.meta_path = [finder for finder in sys.meta_path if "ImportBlocker" not in str(finder)]

    # n8n 1.102: blocked `js` module: https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/pull/16957
    import js
    sys.modules.pop("js", None)


_disable_n8n_mitigations()

import micropip
await micropip.install("openpyxl")
from io import BytesIO
import pandas as pd
import datetime
import base64
import os
from openpyxl import load_workbook
from openpyxl.styles import Alignment, PatternFill

# Get the uploaded Excel files
input_data = _input.all()

# Get project Excel data (from Read Project Excel File node)
project_binary = input_data[0]["binary"]
project_b64_excel = project_binary["data"]["data"]
project_excel_bytes = BytesIO(base64.b64decode(project_b64_excel))

# Get validation rules Excel data (from Read Validation Rules File node)
validation_binary = input_data[1]["binary"]
validation_b64_excel = validation_binary["data"]["data"]
validation_excel_bytes = BytesIO(base64.b64decode(validation_b64_excel))

# Get the validation rules path from the previous node to determine output directory
validation_rules_path = input_data[1]["json"]["validation_rules_path"]
output_directory = os.path.dirname(validation_rules_path)
print(f"Output directory: {output_directory}")

# Load project data
df = pd.read_excel(project_excel_bytes)
print(f"Loaded {len(df)} rows from project file")

# Handle duplicate columns
duplicate_cols = df.columns[df.columns.duplicated(keep=False)].unique().tolist()
if duplicate_cols:
    print(f"WARNING: Duplicate columns found: {duplicate_cols}")

# Clean column names
column_mapping = {col: col.split(' : ')[0] if ':' in col else col for col in df.columns}
cleaned_columns = list(column_mapping.values())

# Load and prepare workbook
wb = load_workbook(validation_excel_bytes)
ws = wb.active

# Unmerge cells in columns D-G
for mr in list(ws.merged_cells.ranges):
    if any(col in range(mr.min_col, mr.max_col + 1) for col in [4, 5, 6, 7]):
        print(f"Unmerging: {mr}")
        ws.unmerge_cells(str(mr))

# Get category column
category_col = ws['B2'].value
print(f"Category column: {category_col}")

# Find category column in data
if category_col not in df.columns:
    for orig, cleaned in column_mapping.items():
        if cleaned == category_col:
            category_col = orig
            break
    if category_col not in df.columns:
        raise ValueError(f"Category column '{category_col}' not found")

print(f"Data type: {df[category_col].dtype}, Unique values: {df[category_col].nunique()}")

# Read validation rules from the Excel
validation_excel_bytes.seek(0)  # Reset the stream
df_excel = pd.read_excel(validation_excel_bytes)
valid_mask = df_excel.iloc[1:, 1].notna() & df_excel.iloc[1:, 2].notna()
validation_data = pd.DataFrame({
    'row': df_excel.index[1:][valid_mask] + 2,
    'group': df_excel.iloc[1:, 1][valid_mask].values,
    'param': df_excel.iloc[1:, 2][valid_mask].values
})

# Define fills
red_fill = PatternFill(start_color='FFCCCC', end_color='FFCCCC', fill_type='solid')
green_fill = PatternFill(start_color='CCFFCC', end_color='CCFFCC', fill_type='solid')

print(f"Processing {len(validation_data)} rules...")

# Helper function
def get_best_column(df, param, group_df):
    matches = [i for i, col in enumerate(df.columns) if cleaned_columns[i] == param]
    
    if not matches:
        return param if param in df.columns else None
    
    if len(matches) == 1:
        return df.columns[matches[0]]
    
    print(f"  Found {len(matches)} columns named '{param}'")
    best_idx, best_count = matches[0], -1
    
    for idx in matches:
        col = df.columns[idx]
        if col in group_df.columns:
            count = group_df[col].notna().sum()
            print(f"    Column {idx}: {count} values")
            if count > best_count:
                best_idx, best_count = idx, count
    
    return df.columns[best_idx]

# Process validation rules
for _, row in validation_data.iterrows():
    r, grp, prm = row['row'], str(row['group']).strip(), str(row['param']).strip()
    
    try:
        # Filter by category
        cat_df = df[df[category_col] == grp]
        
        # Try alternative matching if no exact match
        if len(cat_df) == 0 and ':' in grp:
            cat_df = df[df[category_col].astype(str).str.contains(grp, na=False, regex=False)]
        
        total = len(cat_df)
        
        # Get column and calculate metrics
        col = get_best_column(df, prm, cat_df)
        
        if col and col in cat_df.columns:
            valid_df = cat_df[cat_df[col].notna() & ~cat_df[col].isin([0, 0.0, "0", "0.0", "0,0"])]
            filled = len(valid_df)
            fill_pct = filled / total if total > 0 else 0
            unique_cnt = valid_df[col].nunique()
            unique_vals = valid_df[col].unique()[:10]
            unique_str = ", ".join(map(str, unique_vals))
            if len(unique_vals) > 10:
                unique_str += f"... ({valid_df[col].nunique()} total)"
        else:
            filled = fill_pct = unique_cnt = 0
            unique_str = ""
        
        # Write to Excel
        ws[f'D{r}'] = total
        ws[f'D{r}'].alignment = Alignment(horizontal='center')
        
        ws[f'E{r}'].value = fill_pct
        ws[f'E{r}'].number_format = '0.00%'
        ws[f'E{r}'].alignment = Alignment(horizontal='center')
        ws[f'E{r}'].fill = green_fill if fill_pct > 0 else red_fill
        
        ws[f'F{r}'] = unique_cnt
        ws[f'F{r}'].alignment = Alignment(horizontal='center')
        
        ws[f'G{r}'] = unique_str
        ws[f'G{r}'].alignment = Alignment(horizontal='left')
        
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"  ERROR: {type(e).__name__}: {str(e)}")
        ws[f'D{r}'] = 0
        ws[f'E{r}'].value = 0
        ws[f'E{r}'].fill = red_fill
        ws[f'F{r}'] = 0
        ws[f'G{r}'] = f"ERROR: {str(e)}"

# Save to bytes & return to n8n
with BytesIO() as out_stream:
    wb.save(out_stream)
    out_stream.seek(0)
    result_b64 = base64.b64encode(out_stream.read()).decode()

output_timestamped = f"DDC_Revit_IFC_Validation__{datetime.datetime.now().strftime('%Y%m%d_%H%M%S')}.xlsx"

# Use the same directory as the validation rules file
full_output_path = os.path.join(output_directory, output_timestamped)

return [{
    "json": {
        "filename": output_timestamped,
        "full_path": full_output_path
    },
    "binary": {
        "data": {
            "data":          result_b64,
            "fileName":      output_timestamped,
            "fileExtension": "xlsx",
            "mimeType":      "application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet"
        }
    }
}]

parameters.content:
## ü§ñ AUTOMATED VALIDATION

Processing includes:
- Project data analysis
- Rules-based checking
- Report creation with color coding

üü© Green = data present
üü• Red = data missing

## üîÑ CONVERSION

Automatic conversion Project files ‚Üí Excel

If file already exists, conversion is skipped

## üìÇ SAVE & OPEN

‚úÖ Report saved automatically
‚úÖ Excel opens for viewing

Filename includes date and time

parameters.command: ="{{$node["Setup - Define file paths"].json["path_to_converter"]}}" "{{$node["Setup - Define file paths"].json["project_file"]}}"

parameters.content:
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Troubleshooting
If you encounter errors during conversion, be sure to reference the executable inside the **`datadrivenlibs`** folder. Use this path:

```text
"DDC_Exporter_XXXXXXX\datadrivenlibs\RvtExporter.exe"
```
instead of:
```text
"DDC_Exporter_XXXXXXX\RvtExporter.exe"
```

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Troubleshooting
In n8n versions 1.98.0‚Äì1.101.x, the Python Code node (Pyodide) completely blocks the `os` module, causing this error:

### ‚úÖ Solution  
To avoid this error, **use latest n8n version 1.97** where the `os` module is not blocked.  
You can launch it with the following command:

```bash
npx n8n@latest
```

‚≠ê **If you find our tools helpful**, please **consider starring our repository** on [GitHub](https://github.com/datadrivenconstruction/cad2data-Revit-IFC-DWG-DGN-pipeline-with-conversion-validation-qto). 

Your support helps us improve and continue developing open solutions for the community!

## ‚¨áÔ∏è Only modify the variables here  
‚Äî everything else works automatically

## ‚öôÔ∏è SETTINGS

**Update file paths here:**
- `path_to_converter` - path to converter
- `project_file` - path to your project file (IFC/DWG/RVT)

## ‚¨áÔ∏è Only modify the variables here  
‚Äî everything else works automatically
